node.title: Maryland Announces Initiatives to Combat Anti-Asian Crimes, Which Have Risen Since 2019
node.alt: Maryland Governor Larry Hogan (left) on Monday announced steps to address anti-Asian hate and bias crimes, including enhanced safety and enforcement measures and more community resources, during a news conference in Annapolis. Former Maryland U.S. Attorney Robert Hur is standing center and Hogan's daughter, Jaymi Sterling, an assistant state's attorney in Anne Arundel County, is standing far right.
node.description: Governor Larry Hogan announced new training for police officers, increased funding to fight hate crimes and developed new resources for the community.
node.content:
["Maryland Governor Larry Hogan on Monday announced his plan to address anti-Asian hate and bias crimes that have continued to increase since 2019, the Associated Press reported.", "The initiatives include actions for enhanced safety and enforcement measures, increased access to community resources and additional tools for educators and students.", "\"Our Asian-American community is facing challenges worse than they have seen in decades,\" Hogan said at a news conference. \"The actions that we're announcing here today are the beginning. We will use every tool at our disposal to help provide additional protection to those who are impacted by these crimes.\"", "For the enhanced safety and enforcement measures, the state will update its hate and bias training for law enforcement agencies to include reporting of hate and bias incidents and crimes. Hogan also said a Maryland State Police commander will be named to act as liaison for hate crime and racially biased incidents.", "To increase local resources, Hogan said the state will increase the funding for battling against hate crimes from $3 million to $5 million.", "The Maryland Center for School Safety will develop resources for students, parents and educators on how to identify and report hate and bias incidents. The state will develop alternative reporting channels including community organizations, nonprofits and faith centers, Hogan said.", "President Joe Biden signed new legislation earlier this year that addressed hate crimes throughout the COVID-19 pandemic, particularly on the increase in violence against Asian Americans. The legislation focused on making reporting hate crimes more accessible at local and state levels, NPR reported.", "Hogan said nearly one-third of all Asian Americans say they have experienced some type of discrimination since the beginning of COVID-19 pandemic last year.", "For more reporting from the Associated Press, see below.", "", "
Maryland Governor Larry Hogan (left) on Monday announced steps to address anti-Asian hate and bias crimes, including enhanced safety and enforcement measures and more community resources, during a news conference in Annapolis. Former Maryland U.S. Attorney Robert Hur is standing center and Hogan's daughter, Jaymi Sterling, an assistant state's attorney in Anne Arundel County, is standing far right.
", "Since the coronavirus was first reported in China, people of Asian and Pacific Islander descent have been treated as scapegoats solely based on their race.", "Nationwide data from law enforcement and surveys in Asian communities have shown a significant increase in hate crimes and hate-based incidents since 2019, Hur said, adding that data so far for 2021 is still being compiled.", "\"We look to be on a trajectory for a slight decrease for this year,\" Hur said. \"It depends on how the data for the rest of the year pan out, but the data from 2019 to 2020 show a significant increase within the state of Maryland.\"", "The governor also is focusing on adding ways of reporting hate and bias incidents, including making 211 Maryland a resource for reporting incidents and providing information about services and resources in Asian languages. The Governor's Commission on Asian Pacific American Affairs will conduct outreach efforts regarding the availability of funding.", "The governor said state and local law enforcement agencies will be directed to prioritize diversity in recruiting, and offer incentives for officers who are proficient in multiple languages.", "Hogan made the announcement with first lady Yumi Hogan, who was born in South Korea, and former Maryland U.S. Attorney Robert Hur, who is Asian American and led the statewide workgroup. Jaymi Sterling, Hogan's daughter who served on the workgroup, also attended the announcement."]
